**January Solutions**

David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen, directors

We acknowledge with thanks the contributions of readers who supplied problems used this month: Les Belasco, Reno, (A); Jacques Triplett, San Diego, (B); A. Nonymous, (C); Eric Stoltz, Portland, OR, (D); Burrell Ives Humphrey, Wayne, NJ, (F); and Bill Ahrens, Milpitas, CA, (H). Problem (G) is based on a suggestion by Peggy Kaplan, Minnetonka, MN.

**Problem A**

Matchpts., both vul. You, South, hold:
What call do you make?

Happy New Year.

Welcome to our new, kinder, gentler MSC, so tame that we start off with a problem where the vote is 30-1-1 for the obvious call. A gift of 100 points to most of our Solvers for the holidays; aren't we being nice? Maybe next Christmas we'll feature a different problem. You'll hold in first seat,

♠ A Q J x x ♥ K Q 10 x ♦ A x x ♣ x.

Or maybe a lead problem; after one notrump—three notrump,

♠ K Q J 10 ♥ x x x ♦ x x x ♣ x x x.

Boy, our gentler MSC is really going to be a barrel of laughs; imagine all the scores of 800. The good news is that this month's problems, other than this clunker, have enough meat to them that we don't need to waste much space here.

When we first played matchpoints, we learned the principle that the spade suit was key. Why in the world have we chosen to bury it?

IRA RUBIN: "One heart. With limited strength (albeit juicy spots), it's doubtful that you can get both suits in, so try to inform partner as best you can."

PHILLIP ALDER: "One heart. If my minors were reversed, I would probably opt for one spade, aiming to show both suits, but here we might well belong in diamonds."

SAMI KEHELA: "One heart. Awkward. May lose the spade fit."

CARL HUDECEK: "One heart. I am temporarily ignoring spades, with RHO probably four-four in the majors."

This loss of spades rates to be more than temporary. If you neglect to bid the master suit now, the odds are high that it's gone forever. Yet, it doesn't bother our intrepid panel a whit.

AL ROTH: "One heart. I take no aggressive action, and I hope to slow the bidding down. If I bid two clubs, I might hear three clubs from West and more clubs from East. I will not get shut out after one heart."

It is nice that you would like to slow the auction down; however, one of your opponents has mentioned a suit that you seem to be lacking. This slow-

The six IMP difference I charged mostly to Stone but a little to Roth.

What of Siniscalco and Forquet—did I charge them for their terrible three notrump contract? No, for it cost only one IMP, and I had decided that swings this small were beneath notice. But I did put a "black mark" in their column to indicate an unpunished error.

I have two other types of notations on my books, both of which show up on Deal 111:

South dealer
North-South vulnerable
Closed Room
Open Room

The play was the same at both tables. Singleton club lead, ace winning. Diamond finesse lost to the king; heart ten to North's ace. Two high clubs cashed, then two spades and a ruff. Silodor was down two, 100; Forquet was down three, 500. The U.S. gained five IMP. How should it be charged?

I can't see why any of the Italians should be faulted. Avarelli's spade overcall is reasonable; so is Belladonna's pass over two diamonds. Forquet's opening at the other table is sound, and while Siniscalco's three-diamond bid is questionable, I refuse to charge it, for I probably would have bid three diamonds myself—at IMP scoring, nonvulnerable, with both opponents passed hands.

Really, Roth and Stone created the swing out of thin air—Stone, with his third-hand pass and his courageous vulnerable three-level overcall; Roth, with his pass over one diamond and his excellent penalty double of three diamonds.

So I gave Roth and Stone a credit of five IMP. It is unfair to charge as errors unusual bids or plays which fail, without crediting "operations" which succeed. And, on the Italian side of the

Each issue is mailed when ready, and the post office delivers when it likes. Please don't get uptight if issues arrive irregularly. However, if you skip an issue (e.g., September arrived and August didn't), do let us know. We will replace an occasional strayed issue free of charge. ("Occasional" means one every few years at most.) If more go astray, please look for the problem at your end.

for a splinter than a concentration in one suit. There's almost no chance that two clubs will end the auction."

**Mark Bartusek:** "Two clubs. Assuming that this doesn't get passed out, I will be able to complete a very accurate description of my hand on the next round; partner can make the final competitive decision. A four-diamond splinter would overstate the strength of the hand and hide the important club features. Also, I would like a club lead if we defend against a high-level diamond contract."

Caravelli, Carruthers, Eisenberg, Kokish, Lowenthal and Smith all bemoaned the unavailability of a fit-showing jump to four clubs. Although we, too, prefer this gadget, we are much too nice to complain.

Some preferred a four-diamond splinter.

**Mary & Max Hardy:** "Four diamonds. In our methods, we use concealed splinters. Opener is able to distinguish between a singleton and a void in responder's hand, but does not ask unless interested in a slam—thus, there is no opening-lead blueprint at game contracts."

A very nice convention, assuming that you can convince your opponents to remain silent.

**Marshall Miles:** "Four diamonds. I wish I were slightly stronger, but partner doesn't need much for a slam if his hand fits mine, especially if he has a singleton spade."

That is the problem with four diamonds. Although you are barely of minimum strength, an attractive pattern opposite (short spades, not short clubs) is the key to this hand. Four diamonds, two notrump and four hearts do nothing to discover the solution of the spade-club mystery. Additionally, we do not like to splinter with all of our values in one suit. We consider a typical splinter to be more spread out.

Several rejected four diamonds in favor of two notrump.

**Chip Martel:** "Two notrump. Better hand for a fit-showing jump. However, since neither that nor my own method (where three clubs is a good four-card single raise) is BWS, I'll settle for two notrump (planning to drive to four hearts). Four diamonds is a bit too much for me, particularly since it gives partner no space to wiggle."

**Jeff Rubens:** "Two notrump. It is easier for West to double four diamonds than to bid three diamonds. I have too high a defense-to-offense ratio (with such weak hearts) for a semi-psychic preempt."

**Eric Rodwell:** "Two notrump. Just short of four diamonds. I want to save space, in case partner is strong. Over three clubs, I can jump to four diamonds."

Yes, at least the two-notrump bidders have a chance of getting the auction to go great for them.

Nineties-style bridge is more obstructionist than ever. If you want to be known as a tough opponent, jump to the maximum at every opportunity and hope for the best. Most good bridge players like to be thought of as difficult opponents, so here we present the macho men.

**Mahmood Zia:** "Four hearts. It's hard for them to bid five diamonds—even with six."

**Ira Rubin:** "Four hearts. If three clubs were forcing, it might constitute a good lead-director; however, it permits West to get in rather cheaply. Hence, just leap to four hearts (and don't fret about North's

which can make only if an opponent wins the first club trick, either injudiciously or because he has the singleton ace.

West opened the heart queen, which I won in dummy, East's king falling. I led the nine of clubs (not the seven) to my king, and West put on the ace. West shifted to a small diamond, and dummy's jack forced the ace. The diamond return rode to dummy's king. Now I led the club seven from the table, finessed my own eight, and made 10 tricks for a top.

You see, I was lucky enough to have Norman Kay on my left, in the West position. Never in his life has Norman been guilty of so bad a play as winning the first club if he could hold up, so the finesse was marked.

Obviously, the secret of winning Individuals is to make sure that your opponents are more expert than your partners.

As South, I hold no brief for my partner's three-notrump bid, although it won the tournament for me. I had done my darndest to scream that my hand was worthless except at clubs. But there I was at three notrump, a foul contract

To the "what happened and why" type of tournament report, Edgar brought fearless journalism. Prior to his entry into this realm, even the pungent criticisms of a Moyse were not directed at players. Bidding philosophies, systems, approaches and myths were blamed for failures during the auction; partnership defense was treated similarly when possible. Other writers were even more restrained. For the less disguisable individual errors in play and defense, authors (even Moyse) sometimes retreated behind not naming the player involved.

Every now and then, someone dared to say who had committed a howler during the play. On these occasions, the blow was usually softened by a not-so-gentle reminder that the perpetrator was well known as the best player in 40 counties in three different states, and had enjoyed that status ever since a tot. True, Player X might have fluffed once before, many years ago, during a backroom game for score caddies . . . Of course, all readers already knew that Player X was a leading expert because, even if they had not previously heard of X's exploits (and mostly they had), they could easily work out that X had not sat down in the Spingold final or

level will be too high to continue; if East bids quietly, he probably has a 'real' two-club opener and there will be little point in bidding."

There would be little point in bidding once opener has shown his hand, but you might have tried the effect of bidding just a tad more last round.

**Michael Rosenberg:** "Two diamonds. Keep it low. Maybe I'll get a chance to bid three notrump, which will depict my holding fairly well. I have had bad experiences preempting with hands such as this. (Of course, I've also had bad experiences when my opponents preempt.)"

Wouldn't it be nice to bid like that? Three notrump not only warns them of the club problem, it assures that if the opponents play the contract your partner will think that they saw his hand.

Of course you could start with four diamonds.

**Al Roth:** "Four diamonds. And, if pass—pass—four hearts or four spades, I will bid five clubs."

Rosenberg's opponents get to play the hand double-dummy and double him on the four level. Roth's opponents get to double him one level higher.

**Ira Rubin:** "Four diamonds. Only four diamonds, as a bad split may wreak havoc upon East. Besides, how will partner ever figure out what to lead opposite your five-diamond call, if LHO bids five spades and RHO raises to slam."

It's more likely that RHO will be declarer, so that you will be on lead. Are you contemplating fourth from your longest and strongest?

**Eric Rodwell:** "Four diamonds. Feels right—should be a good save, invites partner to raise with a fit, but leaves East-West room to have an accident."

Yes, they do have plenty of room.

**Gerald Caravelli:** "Four diamonds. I'll bid as far as I'm willing to go. If East is declarer, I'm on lead; if West declares a slam, I can double (and hope)."

**Henry Bethe:** "Four diamonds. Looks about right on loser count."

Maybe at a worse vulnerability.

Many of the three-diamond bidders are also planning to bid again.

**Paul Trent:** "Three diamonds. I intend to bid four clubs after pass—pass—three-of-a-major."

**Dick Freeman:** "Three diamonds. I'll probably follow with four notrump over four of a major."

You know what we think of those plans, so we won't kick a dead horse.

**Chip Martel:** "Three diamonds. With good defense, I won't go crazy, but I am willing to take some space and suggest a save. I suppose three clubs is possible, but I expect to be on lead."

**Jeff Rubens:** "Three diamonds. Bidding two diamonds here suggests the need to find a fit to compete. Pass is acceptable—with no further information, I'd bet against East-West's being able to make their normal contract."

Yes, we agree. Pass has much more chance of success than that lovely two-diamond overcall.

**Phillip Alder:** "Four diamonds. Often, three clubs works with this type of hand, but here I expect to be on lead (if we defend), and they don't rate to end in notrump if left to themselves."

That is the key point. They must be 50-1 to play in a major. Why give them an easy ride?

**Marshall Miles:** "Three diamonds. In my youth, I would have bid two spades, but I don't need desperation tactics (or a
**Board 20; West dealer; Both vulnerable**

The last board concluded a remarkable 50-imp spurt over five boards. On the Vu-Graph, we noticed that Rosenberg intentionally delayed placing his pass card on the tray after Chemla had bid five clubs. This "screen huddling" is entirely ethical and proper. The screen is supposed to conceal fast calls as well as huddles; if a player makes a fast call, his opponent may delay the movement of the tray so that the speed of the call is not known on the other side of the screen. Whether this had any effect on Perron's losing decision to bid the slam we will never know, but the result was a fine one for the U. S. In the Closed Room, West doubled five clubs. The substantial pickup completed a dramatic turnaround and gave the U. S. the match by 23 imps.

**Edgar Kaplan Remembered, II**

*by Jeff Rubens*

**The Tournament Scene**

While the behavioral pot simmered through the late '50s and early '60s, in other dimensions tournaments kept cooking in more or less the usual way. To be sure, "usual" then was a bit different from "usual" now. For example, in the age before fixed partnerships became the norm in serious events, there was some respect for individual contests. Indeed, the Masters Individual was regarded as a premier event. And the contest for winning the most master points in a year (then called the McKenney, now named after Barry Crane) was regarded as significant, both by the general public and by the

tournament crowd. Nowadays, each of these areas enjoys only a small fraction of its former status.

Among the top players, Edgar Kaplan was one of the least capable in individual events. (By far the most successful stars in this universe were the ones with the most placid personalities, such as B. Jay Becker and Norman Kay.) However, in 1957, when Edgar won the McKenney trophy with what was then considered an astronomical masterpoint total (chicken feed in today's inflation-wracked economy), he somehow won the Masters Individual—oops, I mean the Life Masters Individual; even then, events had to be reclassified to reduce the number of in-

four hearts. . . . A grand is possible after a follow-up exchange of cue-bids."

Before we choose between 'a' and 'b,' let's hear from our two 'c's.

CARL HUDECEK: "c. Six diamonds. The direct route to slam. If I had chosen a three-spade advance, and partner then bid three notrump, I would pass."

If we had to make one bid for our lives, we would choose six diamonds. But why should we give up on seven, easy to reach opposite many fitting minimums? As to passing three no-trump, anything we'd print would be censored by the editor, so we had best say nothing at all.

ARTHUR ROBINSON: "c. Four clubs. I assume this is 100% forcing."

Yes, we assume that. Too bad it has nothing to do with your hand. Is this some new system where new suits in competition show voids?

Let's get back to reality and see if we should start with three hearts or three spades. The three-spade bidders are trying to paint a complete picture.

JEFF RUBENS: "b. Three spades, then four hearts. Three hearts first is unlikely to accomplish much. If I can get away with three spades, my later cue-bids will support diamonds and show, roughly, my hand pattern."

KIT WOOLSEY: "b. Three spades, then four hearts, then five diamonds (probably). As I can't show my club void conveniently, this sequence gives the best picture of my hand."

They're not bidding three spades to try to get to spades, but simply to show their shape. Sure, and they'll get that chance if partner bids three notrump. The problem is that partner might end-

play them into a guess by raising to four spades. We'd rather make sure North knows we're showing a monster hand for diamonds while there's still room to investigate.

JOHN LOWENTHAL: "b. Three spades, then five clubs. As in problem A, source of tricks first, then splinters, cue-bids, etc. I plan to drive to slam."

Not bad, but you're lucky you had room to splinter. If partner were unkind enough to rebid four clubs (not really a surprise), then where would you be? You'd have a really hard time convincing him that you have enormous diamond support.

Given South's heart holding, it should be a bit of a surprise that North bids three notrump. Without knowing partner's rebid, it seems that we should make sure we do everything we can to announce our diamonds.

CHIP MARTEL: "a. Three hearts, then four hearts. Should show the ace (with a singleton, I'd probably bid four hearts directly). Slam prospects are too good to bid anything but a slam try in diamonds."

Chip then went on to discuss the merits of four spades as a fit bid, but he didn't like the fact that it took up so much room. We'd rather not make a fit bid with a side void and a side ace. Something like,

♠KQxxx ♥xx ♦KQxx ♣xx,

is more typical.

RON GERARD: "a. Three hearts, then four diamonds. Clearest slam try. Three spades looks like standard rubber bridge perversity . . ."

Or maybe matchpoint perversity.

Ron spent his next few paragraphs talking about ethical problems. If part-

swing for France.

The U. S. woes continued as Zia and Rosenberg bid to a poor slam. Apparently, Zia meant four notrump as "choose a minor," while Rosenberg thought it showed slam interest. After a low heart lead, declarer could have made the slam double-dummy by ducking at trick one, and later stripping North's hand for an endplay, but naturally Zia went up with dummy's ace of hearts and the slam was doomed. Note that on a high-spade lead Zia could (and probably would) have made the contract via the endplay if he takes the ruffing finesse in spades and times the play carefully. The Closed Room contract was five clubs, and the hefty swing pushed the French lead to 27 imps.

France seemed on the road to a substantial victory, but on the next board Perron, North, held,

♠ T52 ♥ Q96 ♦ K52 ♣ 8643,

and heard this auction:
**Solution to "Kantar for the Defense"**

Return a heart, playing partner for the ace-jack. If partner had wanted a diamond promotion (with, say, ace of hearts and queen-jack-nine of diamonds), he would have played the ace and another heart. It's that simple.

If you doubled two diamonds on Deal 7 in October's Challenge the Champs, score yourself 6.

Sure, that fifth heart and useful spade holding were good catches, so maybe the layout was an aberration, and the long-run winner really is:

**Bobby Wolff**: "Pass. I think pass is the percentage call. Game is remote, and a plus score is probable versus one spade."

**Dick Freeman**: "Pass. Take my probable plus. Partner doesn't have four hearts and six-plus points. So game is unlikely, and we could head for a minus in competition."

**Ira Rubin**: "Pass. I'd opt for pass, although two hearts might work if you catch partner with many hearts but few high cards (and probably long clubs)."

**Al Roth** (and Phillip Alder similarly): "Pass. I hope we reap a profit. I don't believe we have a game unless West psyched."

They get 90 points here, not 100, since the inclination of the panel (18 to 14) was to balance and hope there might be a game. Any of you passers that want to send a letter of complaint should be happy that this isn't Roth's "At the Table" column. In that format you would get a small skinny zero, since 620 happened to be par on the actual deal. Accept your 90 points and have a nice day.

**Henry Bethe** (and Carl Hudecek similarly): "Pass. Where's the future opposite a passing partner?"

The future could be slam on little

♠ K x  ♥ x x x x x x  ♦ x x  ♣ x x x.

The South hand is special because the hearts are ace-king-fourth, instead of, say, king-queen-jack-fourth. With our holding, if we catch partner with heart length, we know the combination will play like a dream. The clubs are ruffed with our low trumps, and the ace-king draw the opponents'. With king-queen-jack-fourth of hearts, things would be messier.

**Eric Kokish**: "Pass. One notrump is the only alternative, and it's not unreasonable at this vulnerability at IMPs. Still, I think it's odds-against to make three notrump opposite likely club-spade length, so let's try to go plus on defense."

**Chip Martel**: "Pass. When you have no good bid and length in the opponent's suit, it's usually best to pass. While you could, of course, be cold for four hearts, it is unlikely you will bid it with confidence anyway."

**Jeff Rubens**: "Pass. Game our way is unlikely, I have no comfortable action anyway (one notrump?!), and spades is likely to be a good trump suit for us."

**Michael Rosenberg**: "Pass. . . . I believe game is very unlikely, and bidding (presumably one notrump) will turn a plus into a minus more often than vice-versa."

Okay, okay. Those are reasonable arguments, but so are:

**Gerald Caravelli**: "Double. No reason to assume that one spade is the optimal spot for our side or that it is not for them."

**Steve Weinstein**: "Double. The most likely game is four hearts. Partner's most likely bid is two clubs, over which I will bid two hearts and hope he gets the message. [If we doubled and removed to two hearts, we'd have more than four diamonds.—D.B. & L.C.] One notrump

showing how a declarer could plan an effective pseudo-squeeze scientifically. There were two main themes, leaving entryless winners as a pseudo-threat in dummy, and the principle exemplified by this deal:

East opened one spade; North-South, locating the wrong minor-suit fit, ended in five clubs. West led a spade from three to the queen. East won two spades, then shifted to the king of hearts from king-queen, breaking the link for a major-suit squeeze.

Declarer did not give up. He won the heart; drew two trumps ending in dummy; then played the six of diamonds to the king, a third trump to dummy, spade ruff, another club, the seven of diamonds to the ace and the queen of diamonds, on which South played the nine. GERALD CARAVELLI: "F1. No. I would have made a negative double. Why not?"

Rosenberg, Smith, and Woolsey all would double because their singleton is in the opponents' suit.

Kokish doubles because he's afraid partner will have some diamond length and won't be able to reopen with a double. Lowenthal prefers double, but is afraid of minus 470. Martel doubles, but can live with pass.

MARK BARTUSEK: "F1. Yes. I would pass over three diamonds because a negative double would most likely fetch a three-notrump bid or a penalty pass from partner, neither of which I would enjoy. I admit there are times when we will miss a game, but it seems too risky in the long run to double."

We remain unconvinced either way. Let's now look at the spicier comments on F1.

IRA RUBIN: "F1. No. Double is mandatory, and pass is purgatory."

RON GERARD: "F1. No. . . . Partner won't leave in a double except in months divisible by four."

Is that a shot at us? Last time we checked, January wasn't divisible by four, so we wonder if his attack is directed towards our April/August/December guy, Mr. Woolsey. Nah, it's probably aimed at us. But what's so bad if partner leaves in our negative double? We have an ace and a doubleton in his suit to lead. We'd be more nervous with a third club, which could crash his potential club tricks. Contrary to popular belief, we don't go out of our way to pass partner's "takeout" doubles.

F2 is also fairly simple. Can partner have a good balanced hand? Of course.

What is he to do? The fact that you passed three diamonds makes it unlikely that you'll pull on the five level, so it is very attractive for opener to double with a "penalty" type of hand.

MARK BARTUSEK (and eight others similarly): "Yes, with a two-notrump rebid; what else can he do?"

The only comment we received from a "No" voter was,

JEFF RUBENS: "F2. No. It's a takeout double. Sometimes, you have to make a penalty pass over a preempt to avoid over-encouraging partner to bid."

He seems to be comparing this situation to one where your opponent opens four hearts, and you have ace-queen-jack-nine of hearts but can't double because you "know" partner is pulling. This surely is not the same circumstance.

Gerard and Kokish think North can be 3=3=2=5, and mention Total Tricks. Eric says that North will expect South to take out the double only with extreme shape.

JOHN CARRUTHERS: "F2. Sure. What else is the poor sap supposed to do with, ♠AKJQKJT ♦xx ♣AKxxx? Pass? Is that forcing to double? Only if you're EOK at unfavorable. Looks like a Law problem to me, boys. We have at most 9, they have, say, 11 (although perhaps it's 10 and 12)."

More on that, when we get to F3.

GERALD CARAVELLI: "F2. Yes. Certainly partner could be 3=3=2=5, although I have partners who say that you have to pass with good balanced hands because all these doubles are for takeout. [Maybe one of them is Rubens.—D.B. & L.C.] That is losing matchpoint tactics. I would not pass with,

Two spades was artificial, showing the values for a four-heart bid. The lead of the jack of hearts gave dummy some entries, but nonetheless things looked grim for declarer. I thought his best bet was to float the eight of diamonds, playing South for the nine and North for the ace-king. That lie would permit the eventual discard of clubs after taking a ruffing finesse in diamonds.

Zia did better. He played a heart to dummy (Perron discarding the seven of clubs, showing count), and ran the queen of diamonds to South's ace. Chemla had a problem, and eventually shifted to a club, handing Zia the contract. Perhaps Perron should have worked out to rise with the king of diamonds and protect his partner from this situation, but that is a difficult play to find at the table. The board was a wash-

This is one of the most complex deals I have ever tried to analyze. There are several possible approaches for declarer. Chemla led the ace of clubs. After some thought, Zia tried what seems to be an unfortunate line. He ruffed the club, played a diamond to the king, took a spade finesse, cashed the ace of diamonds, and ruffed a diamond low. Chemla overruffed and returned a trump. It might seem as though Zia can make the contract by ducking, but a spade return from North would leave declarer a trick short. In practice, Zia won with dummy's ace of hearts and went into a long huddle. We in the audience worked out that the contract could be made by ruffing a diamond

right about partner's being very short in diamonds with a good hand, we could so easily have a slam in either of two strains. Hence, my kamikaze cue-bid. Of course, I will have to tell partner that I was asleep on the first round. Passing and then driving to a slam is hardly consistent."

At least he knocks his action (about three times) in his comments.

Our editor always tells us to be brief and to try to condense comments so that The Bridge World can afford to publish. It wasn't easy on this problem, with its three different questions and lots of confused panelists trying to answer F1, F2, and F3. Life would have been much simpler for us if everyone used this approach:

EDDIE KANTAR: "Yes, No, Five hearts. Swimming."

Now that's brevity. Three problems, one-word answer, two-out-of-three correct ain't bad, and 80 points to give you 440 out of 600.
**Solution A**

Suppose you play trumps early, taking two rounds after winning the opening lead. If spades turn out to be four-one, you are in trouble. If you switch to hearts, the defender with four trumps may be able to ruff in and lead a trump, leaving you a trick short. Alternatively, if you take two club ruffs after the second trump you will still face a dilemma: when you lead a fourth round of trumps, the long-trump defender may have another club; should you instead try hearts, the third round may be ruffed, cutting you off from the pitch for your diamond loser.

A superior plan is to duck a trump at

**Problem G**

IMPs; none vul. You, South, hold:
What call do you make?

Bridge World circa 1956: Sonny Moyse would say, "Throw this hand out. Anyone who doesn't respond two diamonds should take up a new game."

Still bidding as if it's 1956:

PAUL TRENT: "Abstain. I bid two diamonds over one spade."

Come on guy, what's up? Surely the forcing notrump should not keep you from being able to play bridge. These problems don't always feature our preferred methods, but that doesn't mean we can't have them imposed on us in a bidding panel. He goes on for several paragraphs with his views of the rules and their fairness. He might win a "nice guy" award, but we don't agree with his viewpoint. (Does that make us not so nice?)

If it were a social game, or a charity game, by all means, let the opponents pick up and do whatever they want. But, in a serious bridge tournament, a lead out of turn is just like any other mistake. Our opponent carelessly forgets to draw the last trump. He plays a side winner. Instead of ruffing it with our tiny trump, should we say, "f. None

of the above. You may take back your play and draw my last trump"? No, of course not. Bridge is a game where you must be focused; not knowing whose lead it is should cause a loss, just as any other lapse in concentration. That's why we have rules. Michael, you can be sure that if you were playing in a world championship, with Edgar, having descended from above (we expect), as your captain, he would be mighty disappointed at your attitude.
